content:
So, rust-analyzer is slowly moving forward with the transition into rust-lang plan and there is one question that came up in regards to our current review "policy". That is we currently self-approve and merge a lot of PRs unless we want some eyes to look over it specifically.
Excerpt from our docs:

It's ok to self-approve if you think you know what you are doing!

So the question here is, is it fine for us to continue doing so after things have moved to the org? This is a rather important topic as a main part of why this workflow exists for us is that we don't have a lot of people working simultaneously on the project, so without this workflow development progress will quickly come to a halt for the project. So we would like to keep this after the move into the rust-lang org, but we deemed this to be a rather important thing to bring up as it deviates from the usual for the org.

I am unsure whether this is the right team to bother, if a different place fits feel free to move the topic :)

I'm not sure we have a rust-lang org wide policy. The compiler team in general requires a non-self review before merging but there are exceptions for some kinds of PRs like rollups, clippy and other tool updates, etc. However, since you're not working in rust-lang/rust (correct me if I'm wrong :smile:), I don't think the compiler team policy really applies to you.
Ye we won't be working in rust-lang/rust, thanks for clarifying :thumbs_up:
